marklogic.body:
I'd like to double-down on my nerdiness for a moment and talk about The Simpsons.
In the episode 'The Prince and the Pauper', the citizens of Springfield-- and the audience-- learn that the man known as Principal Seymour Skinner is, in fact, an imposter.Â The real Seymour Skinner returns to reclaim his identity, but eventually the town decides they like the old Seymour better and run the real Seymour out of town.Â At the end of the episode the townspeople agree to pretend the events of that story never happened, effectively retconning that episode (other than one callback, seasons later).
It was a hated episode for many people who watched the earlier seasons of The Simpsons.Â Matt Groening himself disliked it, and still does.Â The more direct creators of the episode, the writer and showrunners, defend it.Â They say it was meant as a commentary on how people dislike change and react violently to disruptions to the status-quo, and that the feelings of the audience were meant to mirror the feelings of the characters in the show.Â It sounds rather clever at first Blush, but it fails to encompass what that episode did to the universe of the show.
'The Principal and the Pauper' called into question all the previous actions of 'Principal Skinner', given the context that he was a man a role he felt obligated to play.Â His willingness to surrender his life to the 'original Skinner' calls into question his motivations and true feelings.Â To the audience, a character who has been molded over nine seasons has just become strange and suspect.Â The audience reacts not just to the change contained in the episode, but also the effect the episode has on what came before.Â To point at the audience and say 'Hah, I'm lampooning your fear of change!' comes across as a shifting of criticism that doesn't fully address what has actually happened.Â However good your intentions, you're striking a blow against your audience and your fictional universe.
To point at Mass Effect 3 and describe it as a clever commentary on the nature of human life puts me in mind of the reaction to episode.Â Even if this game was marketed as a jumping-in point for new players, its core audience is people who have played the previous games.Â Time has been taken to commit the player to the characters, the concepts, and feel of the Mass Effect universe.Â Throughout the series, emphasis has been put on player control.Â 'Look,' says the marketing team, 'your choices are persistent between games through save files!'Â References are put in to acknowledge the player's agency and will: 'Hey, remember the time you blew up X instead of Y?'Â Even if many of the choices in the third game are fairly shallow (will you get +5 Krogan Power or +5 Salarian Power?) they still play into that concept.Â
Ultimately, none of it matters.Â Press a button, get an ending.Â If life is Fleeting but decisions meaningful, then why are decisions not reflected in the finale?Â What effect did the past two games really have?Â Why must the galactic community we've come to know and love make nearly the same sacrifice as the Protheans before?Â Are we expected to believe that not just individual lives are futile, but all life?Â If that truly is the final message of the game, it's a payoff far outweighed by the cost.Â It's not commentary on human existence; it's a sucker-punch 5 years in the making.
